q: An EC2 instance is connected to an ENI (Elastic Network Interface) in one subnet. What happens when you attach an ENI of a different subnet to this EC2 instance?

o.c: The EC2 instance follows the rules of the older subnet.
The EC2 instance follows the rules of both the subnets.
Not possible, cannot be connected to 2 ENIs.
The EC2 instance follows the rules of the newer subnet.

nt: When you attach multiple ENIs from different subnets to an EC2 instance, the instance becomes multi-homed and can communicate according to the routing rules of all attached subnets. Each ENI maintains its own IP address and security group associations, allowing the instance to participate in multiple network segments simultaneously. This enables complex networking scenarios where an instance needs to bridge different network environments or serve multiple roles across different subnets.

q: You have deployed a three-tier web application in a VPC with a CIDR block of 10.0.0.0/28. You initially deploy two web servers, two application servers, two database servers and one NAT instance for a total of seven EC2 instances. The web, application and database servers are deployed across two Availability Zones (AZs). You also deploy an ELB in front of the two web servers, and use Route 53 for DNS. Web traffic gradually increases in the first few days following the deployment, so you attempt to double the number of instances in each tier of the application to handle the new load. Unfortunately some of these new instances fail to launch. Which of the following could be the root cause? (Choose 2 answers)

o.c: AWS reserves the first and the last private IP address in each subnet's CIDR block so you do not have enough addresses left to launch all of the new EC2 instances.
The Internet Gateway (IGW) of your VPC has scaled-up, adding more instances to handle the traffic spike, reducing the number of available private IP addresses for new instance launches.
The ELB has scaled-up, adding more instances to handle the traffic spike, reducing the number of available private IP addresses for new instance launches.
AWS reserves one IP address in each subnet's CIDR block for Route 53 so you do not have enough addresses left to launch all of the new EC2 instances.
AWS reserves the first four and the last IP address in each subnet's CIDR block so you do not have enough addresses left to launch all of the new EC2 instances.

nt: AWS reserves the first four IP addresses and the last IP address in each subnet CIDR block for internal AWS services, which cannot be used for EC2 instances. With a /28 CIDR block (16 total IP addresses), only 11 addresses are available for instances. When ELB scales up to handle increased traffic, it consumes additional IP addresses within the subnet, further reducing available addresses. The combination of AWS-reserved IP addresses and ELB consumption leaves insufficient addresses for all the new EC2 instances.

q: Which of the following will cause an immediate DB instance reboot to occur?

o.c: You change storage type from standard to PIOPS, and Apply Immediately is set to true.
You change the DB instance class, and Apply Immediately is set to false.
You change a static parameter in a DB parameter group.
You change the backup retention period for a DB instance from 0 to a nonzero value or from a nonzero value to 0, and Apply Immediately is set to false.

nt: Changing storage type from standard to Provisioned IOPS requires a storage migration process that necessitates a DB instance reboot to complete the transition. When Apply Immediately is set to true, this change occurs immediately rather than during the next maintenance window, forcing an immediate reboot to implement the new storage configuration.

q: EBS Snapshots occur [...].

o.c: Asynchronously.
Synchronously.

nt: EBS snapshots occur asynchronously, meaning the snapshot creation process happens in the background while the volume continues to serve I/O operations. The snapshot captures the state of the volume at the moment the snapshot was initiated, but the actual data transfer to S3 happens asynchronously. This design allows applications to continue running without significant performance degradation during the snapshot process.

q: You are tasked with moving a legacy application from a virtual machine running Inside your datacenter to an Amazon VPC Unfortunately this app requires access to a number of on-premises services and no one who configured the app still works for your company. Even worse there's no documentation for it. What will allow the application running inside the VPC to reach back and access its internal dependencies without being reconfigured? (Choose 3 answers)

o.c: An AWS Direct Connect link between the VPC and the network housing the internal services.
An Internet Gateway to allow a VPN connection.
An Elastic IP address on the VPC instance.
An IP address space that does not conflict with the one on-premises.
Entries in Amazon Route 53 that allow the Instance to resolve its dependencies' IP addresses.
A VM Import of the current virtual machine.

nt: AWS Direct Connect provides a dedicated network connection between on-premises infrastructure and AWS VPC, allowing seamless communication without reconfiguration. Using non-conflicting IP address spaces ensures proper routing between on-premises and cloud networks without IP address collisions. VM Import allows migrating the existing virtual machine as-is to AWS, preserving the application configuration and dependencies, eliminating the need to reconfigure the application to access on-premises services.

q: A company needs to deploy services to an AWS region which they have not previously used. The company currently has an AWS identity and Access Management (IAM) role for the Amazon EC2 instances, which permits the instance to have access to Amazon DynamoDB. The company wants their EC2 instances in the new region to have the same privileges. How should the company achieve this?

o.c: Create a new IAM role and associated policies within the new region.
Assign the existing IAM role to the Amazon EC2 instances in the new region.
Copy the IAM role and associated policies to the new region and attach it to the instances.
Create an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) of the instance and copy it to the desired region using the AMI Copy feature.

nt: IAM roles are global resources in AWS and are not region-specific. Once an IAM role is created, it can be used across all AWS regions without needing to recreate or copy it. The existing IAM role with DynamoDB access permissions can be directly assigned to EC2 instances in any region, maintaining the same security policies and access controls throughout the AWS infrastructure.

q: If you want to launch Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances and assign each instance a predetermined private IP address you should:

o.c: Launch the instance from a private Amazon Machine Image (AMI).
Assign a group of sequential Elastic IP address to the instances.
Launch the instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).
Launch the instances in a Placement Group.
Use standard EC2 instances since each instance gets a private Domain Name Service (DNS) already.

nt: Amazon VPC provides complete control over IP address assignment, allowing you to specify predetermined private IP addresses for instances at launch time. Within a VPC, you can define subnets with specific CIDR blocks and assign specific private IP addresses from those ranges to your instances, providing predictable networking configurations that are essential for applications requiring fixed IP addressing.

q: When automatic failover occurs, Amazon RDS will emit a DB Instance event to inform you that automatic failover occurred. You can use the [...] to return information about events related to your DB Instance.

o.c: FetchFailure.
DescriveFailure.
DescribeEvents.
FetchEvents.

nt: The DescribeEvents API call is specifically designed to return information about events related to DB instances, including automatic failover events, maintenance windows, backup activities, and other significant database events. This API provides detailed event information including the source type, source identifier, message content, and timestamps, allowing comprehensive monitoring and troubleshooting of RDS instance activities.

q: You have a Business support plan with AWS. One of your EC2 instances is running Microsoft Windows Server 2008 R2 and you are having problems with the software. Can you receive support from AWS for this software?

o.c: Yes.
No, AWS does not support any third-party software.
No, Microsoft Windows Server 2008 R2 is not supported.
No, you need to be on the enterprise support plan.

nt: AWS Business Support includes guidance and troubleshooting for popular operating systems and AWS components, including Windows Server. While AWS doesn't provide code-level debugging for customer applications, they do offer support for configuration issues, performance problems, and connectivity issues with supported operating systems like Windows Server 2008 R2 when running on EC2 instances.

q: A newspaper organization has a on-premises application which allows the public to search its back catalogue and retrieve individual newspaper pages via a website written in Java They have scanned the old newspapers into JPEGs (approx 17TB) and used Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to populate a commercial search product. The hosting platform and software are now end of life and the organization wants to migrate Its archive to AWS and produce a cost efficient architecture and still be designed for availability and durability. Which is the most appropriate?

o.c: Use S3 with reduced redundancy to store and serve the scanned files, install the commercial search application on EC2 Instances and configure with auto-scaling and an Elastic Load Balancer.

Model the environment using CloudFormation use an EC2 instance running Apache webserver and an open source search application, stripe multiple standard EB5 volumes together to store the JPEGs and search index.
Use S3 with standard redundancy to store and serve the scanned files, use Cloud5earch for query processing, and use Elastic Beanstalk to host the website across multiple Availability Zones.
Use a single-AZ RD5 My5QL instance to store the search index 33d the JPEG images use an EC2 instance to serve the website and translate user queries into 5Q

Use a CloudFront download distribution to serve the JPEGs to the end users and Install the current commercial search product, along with a Java Container Tor the website on EC2 instances and use Route 53 with DNS round-robin.

nt: S3 with standard redundancy provides 99.999999999% durability and 99.99% availability for the JPEG archive at low cost. CloudSearch offers managed search capabilities without the operational overhead of maintaining search infrastructure. Elastic Beanstalk automatically handles deployment, capacity provisioning, load balancing, and automatic scaling across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring high availability for the Java web application while minimizing management complexity.

q: A Provisioned IOPS volume must be at least [...] GB in size.
nt: AWS requires Provisioned IOPS (io1) volumes to be at least 10 GB in size. This minimum size requirement ensures there is sufficient underlying storage infrastructure to support the guaranteed IOPS performance and maintains the ratio constraints between volume size and provisioned IOPS (up to 50:1 ratio for io1 volumes).

q: In Amazon EC2, while sharing an Amazon EBS snapshot, can the snapshots with AWS Marketplace product codes be made public?

o.c: Yes, but only for US-based providers.
Yes, they can be public.
No, they cannot be made public.
Yes, they are automatically made public by the system.

nt: Snapshots containing AWS Marketplace product codes cannot be made public due to licensing restrictions and intellectual property protection. Marketplace AMIs are commercial products with specific usage terms, and making them publicly available would violate the licensing agreements between AWS and the Marketplace vendors. AWS enforces this restriction to protect the commercial interests of Marketplace providers.

q: A company has an AWS account that contains three VPCs (Dev, Test, and Prod) in the same region. Test is peered to both Prod and Dev. All VPCs have non-overlapping CIDR blocks. The company wants to push minor code releases from Dev to Prod to speed up time to market. Which of the following options helps the company accomplish this?

o.c: Create a new peering connection Between Prod and Dev along with appropriate routes.
Create a new entry to Prod in the Dev route table using the peering connection as the target.
Attach a second gateway to Dev. Add a new entry in the Prod route table identifying the gateway as the target.
The VPCs have non-overlapping Cl DR blocks in the same account. The route tables contain local routes for all VPCs.

nt: With non-overlapping CIDR blocks and existing VPC peering connections between Test and both Prod and Dev, along with proper route table configurations containing local routes for all VPCs, communication is already enabled between the peered VPCs. The transitive routing through the Test VPC allows Dev to communicate with Prod without requiring a direct peering connection between them, enabling code deployment from Dev to Prod through the existing network architecture.

q: The [...] service is targeted at organizations with multiple users or systems that use AWS products such as Amazon EC2, Amazon SimpleDB, and the AWS Management Console.

o.c: Amazon RDS.
AWS Integrity Management.
AWS Identity and Access Management.
Amazon EMR.

nt: AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) is specifically designed for organizations with multiple users or systems that need secure access to AWS services. IAM enables fine-grained access control, allowing administrators to grant different levels of permissions to different users, groups, and roles for various AWS services like EC2, SimpleDB, and the Management Console, ensuring the principle of least privilege is maintained across the organization.

q: You have just been given a scope for a new client who has an enormous amount of data (petabytes) that he constantly needs analysed. Currently he is paying a huge amount of money for a data warehousing company to do this for him and is wondering if AWS can provide a cheaper solution. Do you think AWS has a solution for this?

o.c: Yes. Amazon SimpleDB.
No. Not presently.
Yes. Amazon Redshift.
Yes. Your choice of relational AMIs on Amazon EC2 and EBS.

nt: Amazon Redshift is AWS's fully managed, petabyte-scale data warehouse service specifically designed for analyzing massive datasets using SQL queries. It offers columnar storage, data compression, and massively parallel processing (MPP) architecture that can deliver fast query performance at a fraction of the cost of traditional data warehousing solutions. Redshift's pricing model and scalability make it ideal for organizations with petabyte-scale analytical workloads seeking cost-effective solutions.

q: You have set up an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) with the usual default settings, which route each request independently to the application instance with the smallest load. However, someone has asked you to bind a user's session to a specific application instance so as to ensure that all requests coming from the user during the session will be sent to the same application instance. AWS has a feature to do this. What is it called?

o.c: Connection draining.
Proxy protocol.
Tagging.
Sticky session.

nt: Sticky sessions (session affinity) ensure that all requests from a user during a session are routed to the same application instance. This is achieved by using cookies that ELB inserts or recognizes, allowing stateful applications to maintain session data on specific instances. Sticky sessions are essential for applications that store session information locally on instances rather than in external session stores, ensuring consistent user experience throughout a session.

q: You have written a CloudFormation template that creates 1 Elastic Load Balancer fronting 2 EC2 Instances. Which section of the template should you edit so that the DNS of the load balancer is returned upon creation of the stack?

o.c: Resources.
Outputs.
Parameters.
Mappings.

nt: The Outputs section in CloudFormation templates is specifically designed to return values from created resources that users might need after stack creation. By defining an output that references the DNS name of the load balancer (using the Fn::GetAtt intrinsic function), CloudFormation will display this value in the AWS Management Console and make it available through the AWS CLI/API after successful stack creation, providing easy access to the load balancer endpoint.

q: AWS CloudFormation is a service that helps you model and set up your Amazon Web Services resources so that you can spend less time managing those resources and more time focusing on your applications that run in AWS. You create a template that describes all the AWS resources that you want (like Amazon EC2 instances or Amazon RDS DB instances), and AWS CloudFormation takes care of provisioning and configuring those resources for you. What formatting is required for this template?

o.c: JSON-formatted document.
CSS-formatted document.
XML-formatted document.
HTML-formatted document.

nt: AWS CloudFormation templates must be formatted as JSON documents or YAML documents. JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is the original and most widely supported format for CloudFormation templates, providing a structured way to define AWS resources, parameters, mappings, conditions, and outputs in a declarative manner that CloudFormation can parse and execute to provision the specified infrastructure.

q: A user has created an application which will be hosted on EC2. The application makes calls to DynamoDB to fetch certain data. The application is using the DynamoDB SDK to connect with from theEC2 instance. Which of the below mentioned statements is true with respect to the best practice for security in this scenario?

o.c: The user should create an IAM user with DynamoDB access and use its credentials within the application to connect with DynamoDB.
The user should attach an IAM role with DynamoDB access to the EC2 instance.
The user should create an IAM role, which has EC2 access so that it will allow deploying the application.
The user should create an IAM user with DynamoDB and EC2 access. Attach the user with the application so that it does not use the root account credentials.

nt: Using IAM roles for EC2 instances is the AWS best practice for granting permissions to applications running on EC2. IAM roles provide temporary security credentials that are automatically rotated, eliminating the need to store long-term access keys in application code or configuration files. The role with DynamoDB access can be attached to the EC2 instance, and the application can automatically obtain temporary credentials through the instance metadata service, providing both security and operational simplicity.

q: After setting up an EC2 security group with a cluster of 20 EC2 instances, you find an error in the security group settings. You quickly make changes to the security group settings. When will the changes to the settings be effective?

o.c: The settings will be effective immediately for all the instances in the security group.
The settings will be effective only when all the instances are restarted.
The settings will be effective for all the instances only after 30 minutes.
The settings will be effective only for the new instances added to the security group.

nt: Security group changes take effect immediately for all associated instances. When you modify a security group's rules (add, remove, or update inbound/outbound rules), the changes are applied to all instances using that security group without requiring instance restarts or any manual intervention. This immediate propagation allows for quick security policy updates across entire fleets of instances, enabling rapid response to security requirements or network configuration changes.

q: Can a user get a notification of each instance start / terminate configured with Auto Scaling?

o.c: Yes, if configured with the Launch Config.
Yes, always.
Yes, if configured with the Auto Scaling group.
No.

nt: Auto Scaling groups can be configured to send notifications to Amazon SNS topics for various scaling events, including instance launches and terminations. This is configured at the Auto Scaling group level (not the launch configuration) by specifying the notification types and target SNS topics. When enabled, these notifications provide real-time visibility into Auto Scaling activities, allowing administrators to monitor scaling events and respond appropriately to capacity changes.

q: Which Amazon storage do you think is the best for my database-style applications that frequently encounter many random reads and writes across the dataset?

o.c: None of these.
Amazon Instance Storage.
Any of these.
Amazon EBS.

nt: Amazon EBS is specifically designed for database-style applications that require persistent block storage with consistent I/O performance. EBS volumes, particularly Provisioned IOPS (io1/io2) volumes, provide the low-latency, high-throughput random read/write capabilities that databases need. EBS offers data persistence independent of instance lifetime, snapshot capabilities for backups, and the ability to dynamically adjust performance characteristics, making it ideal for database workloads.

q: In the Amazon RDS Oracle DB engine, the Database Diagnostic Pack and the Database Tuning Pack are only available with [...].

o.c: Oracle Standard Edition.
Oracle Express Edition.
Oracle Enterprise Edition.
None of these.

nt: The Database Diagnostic Pack and Database Tuning Pack are advanced Oracle database features that are exclusively available with Oracle Enterprise Edition. These packs provide comprehensive performance monitoring, diagnostics, and tuning capabilities that require the enhanced licensing and feature set of Enterprise Edition. AWS RDS for Oracle makes these features available when using Oracle Enterprise Edition, but they are not included with Standard Edition or Express Edition due to Oracle's licensing restrictions.

q: Will my standby RDS instance be in the same Availability Zone as my primary?

o.c: Only for Oracle RDS types.
Yes.
Only if configured at launch.
No.

nt: In RDS Multi-AZ deployments, the standby replica is always provisioned in a different Availability Zone than the primary instance. This architectural design ensures high availability by protecting against AZ-level failures. If the primary AZ becomes unavailable, RDS can automatically fail over to the standby in the other AZ, maintaining database availability despite infrastructure failures at the Availability Zone level.

q: An administrator is using Amazon CloudFormation to deploy a three tier web application that consists of a web tier and application tier that will utilize Amazon DynamoDB for storage. When creating the CloudFormation template, which of the following would allow the application instance access to the DynamoDB tables without exposing API credentials?

o.c: Create an Identity and Access Management Role that has the required permissions to read and write from the required DynamoDB table and associate the Role to the application instances by referencing an instance profile.

Use the Parameter section in the Cloud Formation template to have the user input Access and Secret Keys from an already created IAM user that has the permissions required to read and write from the required DynamoDB table.

Create an Identity and Access Management Role that has the required permissions to read and write from the required DynamoDB table and reference the Role in the instance profile property of the application instance.

Create an identity and Access Management user in the CloudFormation template that has permissions to read and write from the required DynamoDB table, use the GetAtt function to retrieve the Access and secret keys and pass them to the application instance through user-data.

nt: In CloudFormation, IAM roles can be defined as resources and then referenced in the instance profile property of EC2 instances. This approach allows the application instances to assume the role and obtain temporary security credentials automatically through the instance metadata service. The role contains the necessary permissions to access DynamoDB tables, eliminating the need to hardcode or expose API credentials while maintaining secure, auditable access to the database resources.

q: In an experiment, if the minimum size for an Auto Scaling group is 1 instance, which of the following statements holds true when you terminate the running instance?

o.c: Auto Scaling must launch a new instance to replace it.
Auto Scaling will raise an alarm and send a notification to the user for action.
Auto Scaling must configure the schedule activity that terminates the instance after 5 days.
Auto Scaling will terminate the experiment.

nt: When the minimum size of an Auto Scaling group is set to 1, Auto Scaling ensures that at least one instance is always running. If the running instance is terminated (manually or due to failure), Auto Scaling's health check mechanism detects the missing instance and automatically launches a new instance to maintain the minimum capacity. This self-healing capability is a fundamental feature of Auto Scaling that helps maintain application availability despite instance failures.

q: True or False: Manually created DB Snapshots are deleted after the DB Instance is deleted.

o.c: True.
False.

nt: Manually created DB snapshots are preserved even after the source DB instance is deleted. Unlike automated backups (which are deleted when the DB instance is deleted), manual snapshots are designed for long-term retention and must be explicitly deleted by the user. This allows organizations to maintain database backups for compliance, disaster recovery, or archival purposes independently of the source database instance lifecycle.

q: Amazon S3 doesn't automatically give a user who creates [...] permission to perform other actions on that bucket or object.

o.c: a file.
a bucket or object.
a bucket or file.
a object or file.

nt: AWS follows the principle of least privilege in S3 permissions. Simply creating a bucket or object does not automatically grant the creator permissions to perform other actions (like reading, modifying, or deleting) on that resource. Explicit permissions must be granted through bucket policies, ACLs, or IAM policies. This security model ensures that users only have the permissions they specifically need, reducing the risk of accidental or malicious data exposure or modification.

q: A company wants to review the security requirements of Glacier. Which of the below mentioned statements is true with respect to the AWS Glacier data security?

o.c: All data stored on Glacier is protected with AES-256 serverside encryption.
All data stored on Glacier is protected with AES-128 serverside encryption.
The user can set the serverside encryption flag to encrypt the data stored on Glacier.
The data stored on Glacier is not encrypted by default.

nt: Amazon Glacier automatically encrypts all data at rest using AES-256 encryption, providing strong security by default without requiring any configuration from users. This server-side encryption is applied to all Glacier data, ensuring that archived information remains protected against unauthorized access. The encryption keys are managed by AWS, simplifying the security implementation while maintaining high levels of data protection for archival storage.

q: What does Amazon EBS stand for?

o.c: Elastic Block Storage.
Elastic Business Server.
Elastic Blade Server.
Elastic Block Store.

nt: Amazon EBS stands for Elastic Block Store, which provides persistent block-level storage volumes for use with Amazon EC2 instances. The term 'Store' emphasizes its nature as a storage service that offers flexible, scalable block storage that can be attached to EC2 instances, similar to physical hard drives or SSDs in traditional servers, but with the elasticity and scalability of cloud infrastructure.

q: You have a distributed application that periodically processes large volumes of data across multiple Amazon EC2 Instances. The application is designed to recover gracefully from Amazon EC2 instance failures. You are required to accomplish this task in the most cost-effective way. Which of the following will meet your requirements?

o.c: Spot Instances.
Reserved instances.
Dedicated instances.
On-Demand instances.

nt: Spot Instances provide the most cost-effective solution for fault-tolerant, distributed applications that can handle instance interruptions. Since the application is designed to recover gracefully from EC2 instance failures, it can leverage Spot Instances' significant cost savings (up to 90% compared to On-Demand) while maintaining application reliability. The distributed nature and graceful failure recovery make this workload ideal for Spot Instances, where occasional instance termination is expected but doesn't impact overall application functionality.

q: What does Amazon SWF stand for?

o.c: Simple Web Flow.
Simple Work Flow.
Simple Wireless Forms.
Simple Web Form.

nt: Amazon SWF stands for Simple Workflow Service, which is a web service that helps coordinate work across distributed application components. SWF enables the building, running, and scaling of background jobs that have parallel or sequential steps, managing the dependencies between tasks and tracking their execution state. It's designed for applications where multiple steps need to be coordinated across different services and systems while maintaining state and ensuring reliable execution.

q: Can you specify the security group that you created for a VPC when you launch an instance in EC2-Classic?

o.c: No, you can specify the security group created for EC2-Classic when you launch a VPC instance.
Yes.
No.
No, you can specify the security group created for EC2-Classic to a non-VPC based instance only.

nt: VPC security groups and EC2-Classic security groups are separate entities that cannot be used interchangeably. Security groups created for VPC can only be used with instances launched within that VPC, and EC2-Classic security groups can only be used with instances launched in EC2-Classic. This separation is due to the fundamental architectural differences between the two networking environments and their respective security models.

q: Which two methods increases the fault tolerance of the connection to VPC-1? (Choose 2 answers)

o.c: Establish a hardware VPN over the internet between VPC-2 and the on-premises network.
Establish a hardware VPN over the internet between VPC-1 and the on-premises network.
Establish a new AWS Direct Connect connection and private virtual interface in the same region as VPC-2.
Establish a new AWS Direct Connect connection and private virtual interface in a different AWS region than VPC-1.
Establish a new AWS Direct Connect connection and private virtual interface in the same AWS region as VPC-1.

nt: Establishing a hardware VPN over the internet provides a redundant connection path in case the primary connection fails. Creating a new AWS Direct Connect connection in the same region as VPC-1 provides a dedicated network connection with higher reliability and consistent performance. Having both VPN and Direct Connect connections creates a highly fault-tolerant hybrid network architecture where if one connection method fails, traffic can automatically fail over to the other, ensuring continuous connectivity to VPC-1.

q: How would you improve page load times for your users? (Choose 3 answers)

o.c: Lower the scale up trigger of your Auto Scaling group to 30% so it scales more aggressively.
Add an Amazon ElastiCache caching layer to your application for storing sessions and frequent DB queries.
Configure Amazon CloudFront dynamic content support to enable caching of re-usable content from your site.
Switch Amazon RDS database to the high memory extra large Instance type.
Set up a second installation in another region, and use the Amazon Route 53 latency-based routing feature to select the right region.

nt: Amazon ElastiCache reduces database load and response times by caching frequently accessed data in memory. CloudFront caches static and dynamic content at edge locations closer to users, reducing latency. Upgrading RDS to a high-memory instance type improves database performance for memory-intensive operations. These three approaches address different aspects of application performance: caching reduces backend load and response times, CDN reduces network latency for content delivery, and database resource upgrades improve query processing speed, collectively enhancing page load times for end users.

q: Typically, you want your application to check whether a request generated an error before you spend any time processing results. The easiest way to find out if an error occurred is to look for an [...] node in the response from the Amazon RDS API.

o.c: incorrect.
error.

nt: The Amazon RDS API uses a standardized error response format that includes an 'Error' node when operations fail. Checking for this node allows applications to quickly determine if an API call was successful before proceeding to process the results. This error handling pattern is consistent across AWS services and provides detailed error information including error code, message, and sometimes additional context to help diagnose and resolve issues with database operations.

q: Through which of the following interfaces is AWS Identity and Access Management available? A. AWS Management Console. B. Command line interface (CLI). C. IAM Query API. D. Existing libraries.

o.c: Only through Command line interface (CLI).
A, B and C.
A and C.
All of the above.

nt: AWS IAM is accessible through multiple interfaces to accommodate different user preferences and automation needs. The AWS Management Console provides a web-based graphical interface. The AWS CLI offers command-line access for scripting and automation. The IAM Query API enables programmatic access for custom applications. AWS SDKs and existing libraries provide language-specific wrappers around the API. This multi-interface approach ensures IAM can be used effectively across various operational scenarios from manual administration to fully automated infrastructure management.

q: A [...] is a storage device that moves data in sequences of bytes or bits (blocks).

o.c: block map.
storage block.
mapping device.
block device.

nt: A block device is a storage device that moves data in fixed-size blocks or chunks, typically 512 bytes or 4KB in size. Unlike character devices that handle data as streams of bytes, block devices enable random access to any block within the storage medium. This block-based architecture is fundamental to storage systems like Amazon EBS, hard drives, and SSDs, allowing efficient data management, caching, and optimization for various workloads including databases and file systems.

q: You have just finished setting up an advertisement server in which one of the obvious choices for a service was Amazon Elastic MapReduce( EMR) and are now troubleshooting some weird cluster states that you are seeing. Which of the below is not an Amazon EMR cluster state?

o.c: STARTING.
STOPPED.
RUNNING.
WAITING.

nt: Amazon EMR clusters do not have a 'STOPPED' state. EMR clusters can be in states like STARTING (cluster is provisioning and launching EC2 instances), RUNNING (cluster is active and processing jobs), WAITING (cluster is running but no steps are currently being processed), TERMINATING (cluster is shutting down), or TERMINATED (cluster is no longer running). The absence of a STOPPED state reflects EMR's design as a processing service where clusters are either active or terminated, rather than being stopped and restarted like EC2 instances.

q: A US-based company is expanding their web presence into Europe. The company wants to extend their AWS infrastructure from Northern Virginia (us-east-1) into the Dublin (eu-west-1) region. Which of the following options would enable an equivalent experience for users on both continents?

o.c: Use a public-facing load balancer per region to load-balance web traffic, and enable HTTP health checks.
Use a public-facing load balancer per region to load-balance web traffic, and enable sticky sessions.
Use Amazon Route 53, and apply a geolocation routing policy to distribute traffic across both regions.
Use Amazon Route 53, and apply a weighted routing policy to distribute traffic across both regions.

nt: A weighted routing policy in Route 53 allows traffic to be distributed between multiple regions based on specified weights, enabling an equivalent experience by balancing load across both US and European infrastructure. This policy distributes traffic according to configured ratios (e.g., 50/50 or 70/30), ensuring that both regions share the user load while maintaining consistent application performance and availability across continents, unlike geolocation routing which directs users based on location rather than load distribution.

q: You are building infrastructure for a data warehousing solution and an extra request has come through that there will be a lot of business reporting queries running all the time and you are not sure if your current DB instance will be able to handle it. What would be the best solution for this?

o.c: DB Parameter Groups.
Read Replicas.
Multi-AZ DB Instance deployment.
Database Snapshots.

nt: Read Replicas provide a scalable solution for handling heavy read workloads like business reporting queries by offloading read traffic from the primary database instance. Multiple read replicas can be created to distribute read queries across several instances, improving overall performance and preventing reporting workloads from impacting transactional operations on the primary database. This architecture allows reporting applications to query the replicas while the primary instance focuses on write operations and critical transactional workloads.

q: One of the criteria for a new deployment is that the customer wants to use AWS Storage Gateway. However you are not sure whether you should use gateway-cached volumes or gateway-stored volumes or even what the differences are. Which statement below best describes those differences?

o.c: Gateway-cached lets you store your data in Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) and retain a copy of frequently accessed data subsets locally. Gateway-stored enables you to configure your on-premises gateway to store all your data locally and then asynchronously back up point-in-time snapshots of this data to Amazon S3.
Gateway-cached is free whilst gateway-stored is not.
Gateway-cached is up to 10 times faster than gateway-stored.

Gateway-stored lets you store your data in Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) and retain a copy of frequently accessed data subsets locally. Gateway-cached enables you to configure your on-premises gateway to store all your data locally and then asynchronously back up point-in-time snapshots of this data to Amazon S3.

nt: Gateway-cached volumes prioritize cloud storage with local caching, where primary data resides in S3 and frequently accessed data is cached locally for low-latency access. Gateway-stored volumes prioritize local storage with cloud backup, where all data is stored locally and asynchronously backed up to S3 as snapshots. This fundamental difference determines the storage architecture: cached volumes are ideal when you want to minimize local storage costs and use S3 as the primary data store, while stored volumes are suitable when you need full local data access with cloud backup for disaster recovery.

q: In Amazon RDS, security groups are ideally used to:

o.c: Define maintenance period for database engines.
Launch Amazon RDS instances in a subnet.
Create, describe, modify, and delete DB instances.
Control what IP addresses or EC2 instances can connect to your databases on a DB instance.

nt: RDS security groups function as virtual firewalls that control network access to database instances. They specify which IP addresses, CIDR blocks, or EC2 security groups are permitted to connect to the database on specified ports. This network-level security control is essential for protecting databases from unauthorized access while allowing legitimate application servers and administrative tools to connect as needed, forming a critical layer in the defense-in-depth security strategy for RDS instances.

q: How long does an AWS free usage tier EC2 last for?

o.c: Forever.
12 Months upon signup.
1 Month upon signup.
6 Months upon signup.

nt: The AWS Free Tier for EC2 instances is available for 12 months from the date of account creation. This includes 750 hours per month of t2.micro (or t3.micro in regions where t2.micro is unavailable) instance usage. After the 12-month period, standard pay-as-you-go pricing applies to all EC2 usage. This extended free period allows new AWS customers to explore and experiment with EC2 capabilities without incurring costs during their initial learning and development phase.

q: After you recommend Amazon Redshift to a client as an alternative solution to paying data warehouses to analyze his data, your client asks you to explain why you are recommending Redshift. Which of the following would be a reasonable response to his request?

o.c: It has high performance at scale as data and query complexity grows.
It prevents reporting and analytic processing from interfering with the performance of OLTP workloads.
You don't have the administrative burden of running your own data warehouse and dealing with setup, durability, monitoring, scaling, and patching.
All answers listed are a reasonable response to his question.

nt: Amazon Redshift offers multiple compelling benefits: its massively parallel processing (MPP) architecture delivers high performance as data volumes and query complexity increase; by separating analytical workloads from operational databases, it prevents reporting from impacting OLTP system performance; and as a fully managed service, it eliminates the administrative overhead of hardware provisioning, software patching, backups, and monitoring. These combined advantages make Redshift an attractive alternative to traditional data warehouses, providing scalability, performance isolation, and reduced operational burden.

q: You can seamlessly join an EC2 instance to your directory domain. What connectivity do you need to be able to connect remotely to this instance?

o.c: You must have IP connectivity to the instance from the network you are connecting from.
You must have the correct encryption keys to connect to the instance remotely.
You must have enough bandwidth to connect to the instance.
You must use MFA authentication to be able to connect to the instance remotely.

nt: IP connectivity is the fundamental requirement for remote access to EC2 instances. Whether using RDP for Windows instances or SSH for Linux instances, network connectivity between your local machine and the instance's IP address (through public internet, VPN, or Direct Connect) is essential. Security groups and network ACLs must allow inbound traffic on the appropriate ports (3389 for RDP, 22 for SSH), and routing must be properly configured to establish the connection, regardless of directory domain joining or authentication methods.

q: Does Amazon DynamoDB support both increment and decrement atomic operations?

o.c: Only increment, since decrement are inherently impossible with DynamoDB's data model.
No, neither increment nor decrement operations.
Yes, both increment and decrement operations.
Only decrement, since increment are inherently impossible with DynamoDB's data model.

nt: DynamoDB supports atomic counter operations for both increment and decrement through the UpdateItem API. These operations use conditional writes to ensure atomicity, meaning they complete successfully without interference from other write operations. Increment is achieved by adding a positive value, while decrement is achieved by adding a negative value to the attribute. This atomic capability is crucial for applications requiring consistent numerical updates like counters, voting systems, or inventory management without the complexity of implementing distributed locking mechanisms.

q: You have multiple Amazon EC2 instances running in a cluster across multiple Availability Zones within the same region. What combination of the following should be used to ensure the highest network performance (packets per second), lowest latency, and lowest jitter? (Choose 3 answers)

o.c: Amazon EC2 placement groups.
Enhanced networking.
Amazon PV AMI.
Amazon HVM AMI.
Amazon Linux.
Amazon VPC.

nt: Placement groups pack instances close together within an Availability Zone to minimize network latency and provide high-bandwidth connectivity between instances. Enhanced networking uses SR-IOV to provide higher I/O performance and lower CPU utilization by bypassing the hypervisor for network traffic. HVM AMIs support enhanced networking and provide better performance for modern EC2 instance types compared to PV AMIs. Together, these technologies optimize network performance by reducing latency, increasing throughput, and minimizing jitter for cluster applications requiring tight inter-instance communication.

q: If an Amazon EBS volume is the root device of an instance, can I detach it without stopping the instance?

o.c: Yes but only if Windows instance.
Yes.
No.
Yes but only if a Linux instance.

nt: The root EBS volume of an EC2 instance cannot be detached while the instance is running because it contains the operating system and is actively being used by the instance. Detaching the root volume would cause the instance to crash since it would lose access to its boot device and operating system files. To modify or replace a root volume, the instance must first be stopped, then the volume can be detached, and the instance can be restarted with a new root volume if needed.

q: True or False: When you add a rule to a DB security group, you do not need to specify port number or protocol.

o.c: Depends on the ROMS used.
True.
False.

nt: When adding rules to DB security groups, you must specify the port number that the database engine listens on (e.g., 3306 for MySQL, 1433 for SQL Server, 5432 for PostgreSQL) and the protocol (typically TCP). This specificity ensures that only the necessary database ports are opened for authorized sources, maintaining the principle of least privilege and reducing the attack surface by not exposing unnecessary ports to potential security threats.
